  • 查尔斯国王获赠苏格兰皇冠珠宝
  • 庆祝五月加冕典礼
  • 抗议者高呼“不是我的国王”

周三，苏格兰庆祝了查尔斯国王和他的妻子卡米拉的加冕典礼，举行了盛大的游行和庄严的教堂仪式，并向他授予了英国最古老的皇冠宝石“苏格兰荣誉勋章”。

5 月，查尔斯和卡米拉在伦敦威斯敏斯特教堂加冕，在大约 100 名世界领导人的见证下，这是英国 7 年来最盛大的加冕仪式。

据说，这位74岁的老人对苏格兰有着深厚的感情，9月伊丽莎白女王去世后，他继承了母亲的王位，成为英国和其他14个王国的君主。

但为了承认英格兰和苏格兰在 1603 年王室统一之前曾有不同的君主这一历史事实，苏格兰于周三分别举行了庆祝他加冕的庆祝活动。

人群聚集在爱丁堡著名的皇家大道上，为代表苏格兰生活各个方面的约 100 人组成的人民游行队伍和由数百名军人以及军用管乐队和鼓乐队组成的皇家游行队伍欢呼。

但是，在场的还有大约 100 名反君主主义者，他们发出嘘声并大声高呼“不是我的国王”。

在该市圣吉尔斯大教堂举行的全国感恩节和奉献仪式上，查尔斯被授予苏格兰荣誉勋章——历史悠久的苏格兰皇冠珠宝，在过去的五个世纪里一直在皇家仪式上使用。

其中包括 1540 年为苏格兰国王詹姆斯五世制作的苏格兰王冠，以及 1543 年为苏格兰玛丽女王加冕的苏格兰王冠，以及被认为是 1494 年教皇亚历山大六世授予詹姆斯四世的权杖。

“通过这顶王冠的象征，我们宣誓我们的忠诚，委托您作为我们的国王统治，为所有人民服务，”汉密尔顿和布兰登公爵以及苏格兰最资深的贵族亚历山大·道格拉斯·汉密尔顿在介绍时说道。查尔斯将王冠放在垫子上。

查尔斯回答说：“在接受这顶王冠时，我保证上帝的帮助。”他的长子兼继承人威廉王子和他的妻子凯特也参加了仪式。

命运之石是苏格兰民族的象征，于13世纪被带到英格兰，并于1996年返回苏格兰，也被移至大教堂举行仪式。

爱丁堡城堡鸣响了 21 响礼炮，游行队伍返回荷里路德宫，随后红箭特技飞行表演队进行了飞行表演。

与加冕典礼本身一样，君主制的反对者也提出了抗议，民意调查显示，该制度在苏格兰的受欢迎程度低于英国其他地区。

警方表示，他们逮捕了两名年龄分别为 20 岁和 21 岁的妇女，据称她们试图翻越皇家大道上的人群安全屏障。

苏格兰独立问题仍然是一个突出的政治问题，一些支持分裂的人也希望有一个民选国家元首。

被捕的反君主主义组织“共和国”首席执行官格雷厄姆·史密斯说：“爱丁堡这场毫无意义的虚荣游行将让苏格兰纳税人损失数百万英镑，为什么呢？这样查尔斯就能再次成为一天的焦点。”五月在伦敦举行的加冕典礼上。

迈克尔·霍尔登报道；珍妮特·劳伦斯、彼得·格拉夫和康纳·汉弗莱斯编辑; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 15:21:54 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/scotland-mark-coronation-king-charles-queen-camilla-2023-07-05/ https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/scotland-mark-coronation-king-charles-queen-camilla-2023-07-05/Phil Noble英国皇家/苏格兰加冕（更新 2、电视、PIX） One dead as rare summer storm hits Netherlands

周三，一场罕见的夏季风暴袭击了荷兰，风速高达每小时 145 公里（90 英里），造成至少一人死亡，该国大部分地区的人们被告知待在室内，出行受到严重干扰。

当地警方称，哈勒姆一名 51 岁的妇女因一棵树倒下砸到她乘坐的汽车而死亡。

在阿姆斯特丹，数十棵树被风暴倒塌，导致该市运河沿岸的汽车和船屋受损，造成数人受伤。

国家气象研究所向包括阿姆斯特丹在内的北荷兰省的居民发出了最高级别的红色风暴警报，敦促他们不要离开家，并仅在危及生命的情况下记下紧急服务电话号码。

气象机构 Weeronline 表示，这场名为 Poly 的风暴是荷兰夏季以来最严重的风暴，也是自 2018 年 1 月以来最强的风暴。

荷兰的强风暴通常发生在十月至四月之间。上一次夏季强风暴发生在 2015 年，是一个多世纪以来的第一次。

夏季风暴造成了很大的破坏，因为树木的叶子很重，而且在五月和六月异常漫长的干旱期间，许多树木都变得脆弱。

阿姆斯特丹史基浦机场是欧洲最繁忙的枢纽之一，发言人表示，该机场取消了 400 多个航班，预计至少在当地时间下午 4 点（格林威治标准时间 1400）之前交通将受到限制。

火车运营商 NS 和 Arriva 停止了该国北部的所有服务，阿姆斯特丹北部的一条高速公路因倒下的树木而关闭。

风暴将在该国北部向东移动，预计下午强度将减弱。

据媒体报道，7 月 4 日周末在费城发生的一系列大规模枪击事件中，一名嫌疑人在费城被捕，周三因五项谋杀罪和其他指控在法庭上受审，不得保释。

费城官员周二表示，嫌疑人名叫金布雷迪·卡里克 (Kimbrady Carriker)，现年 40 岁，周一晚间，他们用 AR-15 型步枪随机向受害者射击，随后被拘留，当时他身穿防弹背心，戴着滑雪面罩。

枪击事件中丧生的五名男子年龄从15岁到59岁不等。警方称，两名受伤儿童分别为 2 岁和 13 岁。

地方检察官拉里·克拉斯纳周三在接受美国有线电视新闻网采访时表示，当局尚未确定动机。嫌疑人与任何受害者都没有明显的联系，这些受害者是在一个长假周末被枪杀的，在这个枪支暴力几乎司空见惯的国家，发生了一系列大规模枪击事件。

根据枪支暴力档案馆的数据，从周五晚上到周三早上，全国共发生了 16 起大规模枪击事件，造成 15 人死亡、94 人受伤，该档案馆将大规模枪击事件定义为四人或四人以上受伤或死亡的枪击事件，而不是四人或四人以上受伤或死亡的枪击事件。包括射手。

布伦丹·奥布莱恩 (Brendan O'Brien) 芝加哥报道; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 14:37:13 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/suspect-philadelphia-mass-shooting-arraigned- Five-murder-charges-cbs-news-2023-07-05/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/suspect-philadelphia-mass-shooting-arraigned- Five-murder-charges-cbs-news-2023-07-05/Brendan O'Brien美国拍摄/（更新2） Palestinians defiant and angry after Israel's Jenin raidSummary:
  • 以色列军队在两天行动后撤出
  • 居民回家时街道被毁，汽车被烧毁
  • 巴勒斯坦权力机构领导人在葬礼上质问

巴勒斯坦武装分子周三在杰宁游行，愤怒的人群与巴勒斯坦权力机构高级官员对峙，指责他们软弱，这是以色列多年来在被占领的约旦河西岸进行的最大规模军事行动之一。

以色列军方称，这次行动为期两天，目标是杰宁难民营的基础设施和武装派系的武器库，造成街道被毁和汽车被烧毁，并引发了整个阿拉伯世界的愤怒。

这场入侵始于深夜的无人机袭击，随后又出动了 1000 多名以色列士兵进行扫荡，造成至少 12 名巴勒斯坦人死亡，约 100 人受伤，其中大多数是武装分子。

一名以色列士兵也在行动中丧生。

营地居民穆罕默德·曼苏尔 (Mohammad Mansour) 说：“我们呆在房子里，但随后他们切断了电源，然后停水。”装甲推土机撕毁了街道，暴露了路边炸弹，切断了电缆和水管。 “我们最终耗尽了面包和补给，我们很饿，我从来没有经历过这样的日子。”

在为 10 名死者举行的葬礼上，巴勒斯坦权力机构（对西岸部分地区进行名义上的治理的机构）的三名高级领导人在面对包括数十名枪手在内的数千人高呼“出去！出去！”

周二晚上以色列军队撤出后，伊朗支持的伊斯兰圣战组织和其他武装派别的领导人声称取得了胜利，返回营地的居民的情绪似乎充满挑衅。

“感谢上帝，他们没有得到他们想要的东西。年轻人很好，家庭很好，营地也很好，”六个孩子的父亲穆塔塞姆·埃斯塔蒂亚（Mutasem Estatia）在经历了两个晚上的隔离后告诉路透社，其中一名被以色列拘留。

“有 12 名烈士，我们为他们感到自豪，但考虑到袭击的规模，我们预计会造成更多损失。”

以色列军队称，以色列军队拘留了 150 名武装分子嫌疑人，缴获了藏匿的枪支和路边地雷，包括清真寺下的一个军火库，并摧毁了一个指挥中心。声明称，所有被杀的巴勒斯坦人都是武装战士。伊斯兰圣战组织拥有七名成员，哈马斯则拥有另一名成员。

随着军队连夜撤军，以色列报告称，从哈马斯控制的另一块巴勒斯坦领土加沙地带发射了火箭弹。火箭被击落，以色列空军袭击了哈马斯在加沙的目标，没有造成人员伤亡。

杰宁爆发暴力事件的又一迹象是，一名巴勒斯坦人在特拉维夫驾车撞向行人，并大肆持刀刺伤，造成八人受伤，随后被枪杀。哈马斯声称他是一名成员。

以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡周二警告说，杰宁行动不太可能是“一次性”，并表示这将是“定期入侵和持续控制该领土的开始”。

伊斯兰圣战武装组织圣城旅的发言人则表示，“每条小巷和街道很快就会变成冲突和战场。”

巴勒斯坦当局的软弱

以色列这次行动的规模是20年来最大的一次，这表明杰宁的激进组织实力不断增强，以色列估计该地区近一半的人口隶属于伊斯兰圣战组织或哈马斯。

它还突显了大约30年前奥斯陆和平协议后成立的巴勒斯坦权力机构的弱点，该权力机构无法对以色列或杰宁或纳布卢斯附近的激进组织施加影响。

这两个城市都是巴勒斯坦抵抗运动的传统中心，但随着过去两年席卷约旦河西岸的暴力浪潮，它们的地位变得更加明显。

在杰宁，社交媒体上流传的视频显示，数百人凌晨聚集在受到严密保护的巴勒斯坦权力机构总督办公室前，向 5 米高的墙壁投掷石块。

以色列一直强烈批评巴勒斯坦权力机构及其87岁的总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯，指责他们未能遏制好战组织。巴勒斯坦权力机构官员则表示，以色列故意削弱其权威，使其无法实施任何控制。

调查显示，近 80% 的巴勒斯坦人希望阿巴斯辞职，但由于没有指定继任者，而且近 20 年来没有举行选举，目前尚不清楚谁可能取代他。

哈里王子周三奋力将针对鲁珀特·默多克的英国报纸部门的电话窃听诉讼送上审判，要求伦敦高等法院让他依赖英国王室与出版商之间所谓的“秘密协议”。

查尔斯国王的小儿子哈里正在起诉默多克的新闻集团报业 (NGN)，指控其从 20 世纪 90 年代中期到 2016 年期间代表其小报《太阳报》和现已解散的《世界新闻报》实施多项非法行为。

NGN 在过去 10 年里解决了 1000 多起电话窃听案件，并于 4 月份申请驳回哈利的索赔， 认为他应该更早采取行动。

哈里表示，他直到 2019 年才提起诉讼，因为白金汉宫和 NGN 高级人士之间达成了一项协议，即在针对 NGN 提起的所有其他电话窃听诉讼结束之前，王室将推迟提起任何诉讼。 NGN 否认有任何此类协议。

周三，哈利的律师试图依靠所谓的协议来驳回 NGN 的请求，并允许该案在一月份的审判中进行审理，英国演员休·格兰特也将提出类似的主张。

哈里声称 NGN 记者或代表他们行事的私人调查员非法拦截了他的语音邮件信息（通常称为电话窃听），并通过欺骗手段获取了电话账单和医疗记录等私人信息，NGN 对此予以否认。

哈里王子的代表戴维·舍伯恩 (David Sherborne) 辩称，有明确证据表明 NGN 与王室之间达成了协议，这意味着哈里王子无法提前提起诉讼。

这位王位第五顺位继承人在 4 月份公开的一份证人声明中表示，NGN“在 2020 年以巨额资金解决了他弟弟威廉王子的索赔……而没有告知任何公众”。

白金汉宫尚未发表评论，威廉的办公室此前表示无法对正在进行的法律诉讼发表评论。 NGN 四月份拒绝就是否与 William 达成和解发表评论。

哈里还表示，他试图在已故伊丽莎白女王的支持下推进针对 NGN 的案件，但遭到 NGN 和王室助手的阻挠。

根据 4 月份发布的电子邮件，王室工作人员曾就 2017 年和 2018 年哈里的诉讼与默多克英国子公司 News UK 现任首席执行官丽贝卡·布鲁克斯 (Rebekah Brooks) 和新闻集团(NWSA.O)首席执行官罗伯特·汤姆森 (Robert Thomson) 进行了沟通。

舍伯恩周三在法庭文件中辩称，NGN 没有提供布鲁克斯和汤姆森的任何证据，“尽管他们的证据被认为是关键的”。

NGN 的律师表示，该公司没有提供 Brooks 和 Thomson 的证据，因为 2012 年据称达成该协议时，他们并不在 NGN 工作。

出版商还辩称，即使白金汉宫和出版商之间达成了秘密协议，在其他电话窃听指控结束之前，该协议也不会适用。

哈里针对 NGN 的诉讼是他针对英国报纸出版商提起的四起诉讼之一，其中包括针对镜报集团报业 (MGN) 的类似索赔，他在其中寻求约 44 万英镑（56 万美元）的损失赔偿。

上个月，他在 MGN 诉讼中作证，成为 130 多年来第一位出现在证人席上的英国高级王室成员。

萨姆·托宾报道；编辑：Devika Syamnath ; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 13:12:07 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/prince-harry-fights-Trial-hacking-case-against-murdochs-uk-group-2023-07-05/ https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/prince-harry-fights-Trial-hacking-case-against-murdochs-uk-group-2023-07-05/Sam Tobin英国皇室成员/哈里法庭（PIX） Inside Ukraine's tech push to counter Russian 'suicide' drone threatSummary:
  • 乌克兰和俄罗斯正在进行战时技术军备竞赛
  • 基辅旨在以创新方式击落俄罗斯无人机
  • 尽管受到俄罗斯袭击，乌克兰无人机产量仍在蓬勃发展
  • 国家计划希望在2023年采购20万架无人机

上个月末，在基辅市中心的一个地下室里，数百名工程师和创新者在远离窥探的地方会见了高级军事官员，集思广益，讨论如何更好地压制仍在摧毁乌克兰城市的廉价俄罗斯自杀式无人机。

这是一次罕见的近距离观察乌克兰与俄罗斯的技术军备竞赛，这场军备竞赛利用了以国家风险资本为种子的私营部门创新，并在蓬勃发展的战时工业中生产了数千架战斗无人机。

乌克兰副总理兼数字化转型部长米哈伊洛·费多罗夫在会议间隙表示：“今天的战争是技术性的，技术和战场每天都在发生变化。”

路透社是唯一受邀参加此次活动的媒体机构，高级陆军官员和部长与工程师和古怪的爱好者混在一起。一名身穿短裤、戴着棒球帽的男子腋下夹着一架大型无人机。

英国周三在拍卖会上出售了一份政府债券，该债券将向投资者支付5.668%的年回报率——这是自2007年以来出售的所有国债的最高收益率，因为市场预期英格兰银行将进一步加息，因此要求额外回报。

英国债务管理办公室出售了 40 亿英镑（50.8 亿美元）的政府债券，将于 2025 年 10 月到期，吸引了强劲的需求，发行量为 2.77 倍，高于此前 6 月 7 日出售国债的 2.34 倍。

上一次英国国债拍卖的平均收益率较高是在 2007 年 6 月，当时出售了 25 亿磅五年期英国国债，平均收益率为 5.790%。

在此之前，收益率最高出现在1999年9月，当时出售了27亿磅10年期英国国债，平均收益率为5.694%。

不到两年前——在英国央行开始加息之前，通货膨胀接近 2% 的目标——政府债券在拍卖中的收益率低于 1%。

这次拍卖凸显了今年英国政府借贷成本的飙升。 2025 年 10 月金边债券上个月在拍卖会上出售时，收益率为 4.874%，而在 1 月份推出时，向投资者支付的收益率为 3.634%。

上个月，英国央行出人意料地将主要利率从 4.5% 上调至5%，因为行长安德鲁·贝利 (Andrew Bailey) 表示，通胀看起来比预期更为持久，而金融市场目前预计利率将在 12 月份达到峰值 6.25%。

5 月份消费者价格通胀保持在 8.7%，英国央行最新预测显示，到今年年底，消费者价格通胀将降至略高于 5%，到 2025 年初将降至 2% 以下。

因此，投资者经通胀调整后的实际回报可能远低于 20 世纪 90 年代末英国国债上次定期获得类似名义收益率时的回报。

2025 年 10 月的英国国债也不同寻常，因为其收益率高于其他类似期限的国债。 NatWest 的债券策略师上周将其描述为“英国拟合曲线上最便宜的债券之一”。

周一，基准两年期英国国债收益率达到 5.406% 的峰值，为 2008 年 6 月以来的最高水平，周三格林尼治标准时间 0945 点，该收益率下降 4 个基点至 5.28%。

中国周一表示，将对用于计算机芯片和其他零部件的镓和锗产品实施出口限制，以保护国家安全利益。

The decision, widely seen as retaliation for US curbs on sales of technologies to China, raised concerns that China might eventually limit exports of other materials, notably rare earths, whose production China dominates.

In 2010, China restricted exports of rare earths to Japan following a territorial dispute, sending prices soaring and Japan scrambling to find alternative sources. Beijing said the curbs were based on environmental concerns.

Below are some facts about rare earths, about China's dominance of the sector, and what countries are doing to ease their dependence on China for the materials.

WHAT ARE RARE EARTHS AND HOW ARE THEY USED?

Rare earths are a group of 17 elements used in products from lasers and military equipment to magnets found in electric vehicles, wind turbines, and consumer electronics such as iPhones.

The 17 elements are: lanthanum, cerium, praseodymium, neodymium, promethium, samarium, europium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, holmium, erbium, thulium, ytterbium, lutetium, scandium, yttrium.

HOW DOMINANT IS CHINA IN THE RARE EARTHS SUPPLY CHAIN?

Mining: China accounted for 70% of world mine production of rare earths in 2022, followed by the United States, Australia, Myanmar and Thailand, United States Geological Survey (USGS) data shows.

Processing: China is home to at least 85% of the world's capacity to process rare earth ores into material manufacturers can use, according to research firm Adamas Intelligence in 2019.

Exports: Chinese exports of rare earths have declined. The country exported 20,987 metric tonnes in the first five months of 2023, down 4.4% year-on-year, Chinese customs data showed.

China exported 48,728 metric tonnes of rare earths in 2022, down 0.4% year-on-year.

The United States sources most of its rare earth imports from China, but that dependence has eased to 74% between 2018 and 2021, from 80% during 2014 to 2017.

WHICH COUNTRIES HAVE THE MOST RARE EARTHS RESERVES?

China is estimated to have 44 million metric tonnes of rare earth oxide (ROE) equivalent in reserves, or 34% of the world total, USGS data showed.

Vietnam, Russia and Brazil are estimated to have just over 20 million metric tonnes each, while India has 6.9 million, Australia has 4.2 million and the United States has 2.3 million metric tonnes.

WHAT HAPPENED IN 2010?

In 2010, China withheld exports of rare earth to Japan during a row over disputed islands. Beijing then curbed global exports of rare earths, saying it was trying to curtail pollution and preserve resources.

Japan, the European Union and the United States successfully challenged China's action in a case at the World Trade Organization.

The episode led Japan, which had relied on China for virtually all of its rare earths, to find alternative suppliers to ease its reliance on China. It invested in Australian producer Lynas (LYC.AX) and had reduced the share of its imports of rare earths from China to 58% by 2018.

WHY IS IT HARD FOR OTHER COUNTRIES TO RAMP UP PRODUCTION?

Rare earths are relatively abundant but occur in low concentrations and are usually found mixed together with one another, or with radioactive elements such as uranium and thorium.

The chemical properties of rare earths make them difficult to separate from surrounding materials, and processing generates toxic waste.

Lax environmental standards enabled China to build its dominance in rare earths in recent decades as Western producers left the industry.

WHAT ARE OTHER COUNTRIES DOING TO REDUCE RELIANCE ON CHINA?

Western countries have ramped up support to boost domestic production of critical minerals including rare earths.

Australia, Canada, the European Union and the United States have set out policies and support packages for their critical minerals sectors.

Las Vegas-based MP Materials (MP.N) mines rare earth oxides at the Mountain Pass mine in California, but ships them to China for processing into neodymium and other rare earth metals, as there is no final processing in the United States.

Electric vehicle maker Tesla (TSLA.O) is moving away from rare earths in future models to mitigate environmental and supply risks, as the rare earth industry struggles to meet demand.

CHINA QUOTA

China raised its full-year mining quota for rare earths for the fifth consecutive year in 2022 to 210,000 metric tonnes, up 25% from a year earlier.

The quota system, usually issued in two batches a year, was put in place in response to China's longstanding problems with illegal mining.

Quotas for mining in the first batch of this year also increased.

WHY DID ISRAEL ATTACK JENIN?

杰宁在哪里？那里的生活怎么样？

杰宁是一座山地小城市，位于约旦河西岸以北，靠近以色列边境，有一个拥挤的同名混凝土煤渣砖难民营，可容纳约 14,000 人。他们是 1948 年以色列建国时被剥夺土地的巴勒斯坦人的后裔，大多数人贫困且失业。这种严酷的传统导致了对以色列的顽固敌意和对巴勒斯坦激进组织的支持。

杰宁难民营的意义是什么？

杰宁是第二次起义期间最严重流血事件的发生地，这场起义始于 2000 年美国支持的和平谈判破裂，并升级为以色列与激进组织之间的武装冲突。

WHAT MILITANT GROUPS ARE PRESENT IN JENIN?

以色列-巴勒斯坦冲突的历史是怎样的？

1948 年以色列建国，击败了中东各地的阿拉伯军队，导致数十万巴勒斯坦难民流散到更广阔的地区，巴勒斯坦人称之为“灾难”。

Ukraine stepped up its efforts to join NATO after Russia invaded last year, arguing that the security assurances given by Moscow, Washington and London when it relinquished its nuclear arsenal to Russia in 1994 were clearly worthless.

While eastern European countries say some sort of a road map should be offered to Kyiv at a NATO summit in Vilnius on Tuesday and Wednesday, the United States and Germany are wary of any move that might take the alliance closer to war with Russia.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has cited NATO's expansion towards Russia's borders over the past two decades as a key reason for his decision to send tens of thousands of troops into neighbouring Ukraine on Feb. 24, 2022.

Any expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization must be agreed by all 31 members, and NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has already ruled out a formal invitation for Kyiv at the summit.

Following are the steps that Ukraine has taken on its way to NATO membership, a possible compromise over the next steps - and Russia's view of the developments.

AN UNMAPPED PATH

In 2008, NATO agreed at a Bucharest summit that Ukraine - which was part of the Moscow-ruled Soviet Union until its 1991 demise - could eventually join the alliance.

But NATO leaders did not give Kyiv a so-called Membership Action Plan (MAP) laying out a road map for bringing it closer to the bloc. Moscow then illegally annexed Crimea from Ukraine in 2014 and backed separatist proxies in eastern Ukraine.

In a rare visit to Kyiv this April, Stoltenberg said Ukraine's "rightful place" was in NATO but later made clear it would not be able to join while the war with Russia, whose forces now occupy more of Ukraine's east and south, rages on.

At the start of June, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said his nation understood this position, but at the end of the month he repeated calls for Ukraine to receive a "political invitation" to NATO at the summit.

Under the MAP process followed by other former communist countries in eastern Europe, candidates have to prove they meet political, economic and military criteria and are able to contribute militarily to NATO operations.

Since 1999, most countries aiming to join NATO have participated in a MAP although this procedure is not mandatory: Finland and Sweden , formerly neutral states which worked closely with NATO, were invited to join the alliance directly.

It is unclear what Ukraine's path to membership will look like as more and more countries, Britain and Germany amongst them, suggest skipping the MAP process.

With such a move, NATO could address demands by Kyiv and its allies in eastern Europe to go beyond the language of the 2008 Bucharest summit agreement without offering Ukraine an actual invitation or timetable.

Ukraine's military has taken major steps towards NATO standards since Russia's all-out invasion. The process is accelerating as its Soviet-built arms and ammunition gradually run out and the West trains Ukrainian troops according to NATO standards and sends more and more advanced weaponry.

WHY IS UKRAINIAN MEMBERSHIP SO SENSITIVE?

A mutual assistance clause lies at the heart of the alliance, which was formed in 1949 with the primary aim of countering the risk of a Soviet attack on allied territory.

It is cited as one of the main reasons why Ukraine cannot join NATO while in conflict with Russia, as this might immediately draw the alliance into an active war.

The clause, Article 5 of NATO's Washington Treaty, states that an attack on one ally is considered an attack on all allies.

Stoltenberg has made clear that, while NATO must discuss options for giving Ukraine security assurances for the time after the war, security guarantees under Article 5 will only be provided to full members of the alliance.

The Kremlin portrays the expansion as evidence of Western hostility to Russia - something Western powers deny, saying the alliance is wholly defensive in nature.

Moscow has said it would cause problems for many years to come if Ukraine joined NATO and has warned of an unspecified response to ensure its security.

Real estate mogul Ron Weiser has been one of the biggest donors to the Michigan Republican Party, giving $4.5 million in the recent midterm election cycle. But no more.

Weiser, former chair of the party, has halted his funding, citing concerns about the organization's stewardship. He says he doesn't agree with Republicans who promote falsehoods about election results and insists it's "ludicrous" to claim Donald Trump, who lost Michigan by 154,000 votes in 2020, carried the state.

"I question whether the state party has the necessary expertise to spend the money well," he said.

The withdrawal of bankrollers like Weiser reflects the high price Republicans in the battleground states of Michigan and Arizona are paying for their full-throated support of former President Trump and his unsubstantiated claims that the 2020 election was stolen from him.

The two parties have hemorrhaged money in recent years, undermining Republican efforts to win back the ultra-competitive states that could determine who wins the White House and control of the US Congress in next November's elections, according to a Reuters review of financial filings, plus interviews with six major donors and three election campaign experts.

Arizona's Republican Party had less than $50,000 in cash reserves in its state and federal bank accounts as of March 31 to spend on overheads such as rent, payroll and political campaign operations, the filings show. At the same point four years ago, it had nearly $770,000.

The Michigan party's federal account had about $116,000 on March 31, a drop from nearly $867,000 two years ago. It has yet to disclose updated financial information for its state account this year.

The two parties have "astonishingly low cash reserves," said Seth Masket, director of the non-partisan Center on American Politics at the University of Denver, adding that state parties play a key election role, helping promote candidates, fund get-out-the-vote efforts, pay for ads and recruit volunteers.

"Their ability to help candidates is severely limited right now."

The Arizona party spent more than $300,000 on "legal consulting" fees last year, according to its federal filings, which do not specify the type of legal work paid for.

In that period, legal fees were paid to a firm that had filed lawsuits seeking to overturn Trump's defeat in Arizona, according to separate campaign and legal disclosures. Money was also paid to attorneys who represented Kelli Ward, the former party chair when the Justice Department subpoenaed her over her involvement in a plan to falsely certify to Congress that Trump, and not Democratic President Joe Biden, had won Arizona, plus when a congressional committee subpoenaed her phone records.

More than $500,000 was also spent in Arizona on an election night party and a bus tour for statewide Trump-backed candidates last year, the financial filings show. All of those candidates, who supported the former president's election-steal claims, lost in last November's midterms.

It's not just Weiser who's had enough.

Five other Republican donors to the Arizona or Michigan parties, who have each donated tens of thousands of dollars over the past six years, told Reuters they had also ceased giving money, citing state leaders' drives to overturn the 2020 election, their backing of losing candidates who support Trump's election conspiracy and what they view as extreme positions on issues like abortion.

"It's too bad we let the right wing of our party take over the operations," said Jim Click, whose family has been a longtime major Republican donor in Arizona. He and other donors said they would give money directly to candidates or support them through other political fundraising groups.

Kristina Karamo, chair of the Michigan state party, didn't respond to a request for comment for this story. In the campaign for her position, she said that she wanted to break ties with established donors, accusing them of exploiting the party for their own gain, and wants to rely more on grassroots members.

Ward, who stepped down as Arizona party chair in January after four years at the helm, told Reuters that she and her team had always had revenues to cover outgoings and had left her successor at least three months' operating expenses plus a "robust fundraising operation."

Dajana Zlaticanin, a spokesperson for new chair Jeff DeWit, said that when he took over, "cash reserves were extremely low and previous bills kept coming in." Contributions are on the uptick, she said, with over $40,000 raised in May.

The Republican National Committee, which oversees Republican political operations nationally, didn't respond to a request for comment about the finances of the two state parties.

'I SEE NO SUN COMING OUT'

Arizona and Michigan, both won by Biden in 2020, are among just a handful of swing states that will likely decide the race for the presidency in November 2024.

Not all Republican parties have fared as badly financially as Arizona and Michigan. For example, the swing state of North Carolina - where Republican leaders haven't focused so heavily on Trump's election-steal fight - ended 2022 with nearly $800,000 in its federal accounts, according to the filings.

It is difficult to get a complete picture of parties' finances, though, given time lags in disclosures and because not all of their accounts are subject to reporting requirements.

Furthermore, state parties don't rely solely on individual donors, they also receive money from national party organizations, outside groups and political action committees.

Michigan was a hotbed of conspiracy theories after Trump lost the 2020 election, and this month Karamo was fined by a county judge for filing a lawsuit that made unfounded claims about voting irregularities in Detroit.

Tensions over transparency have started to boil over.

Last week former state party budget chairman Matt Johnson launched a broadside against Karamo, two days after she removed him from his post, accusing her of keeping his committee in the dark about the party's finances.

"As far as we could tell from the piecemeal information we received, the party's fundraising had been extremely meager, and the spending was so far out of proportion with income as to put us on the path to bankruptcy," he said.

Jason Roe, a former executive director of the Michigan Republican Party, said the financial figures disclosed so far by the party underscore the difficult task of supporting operations without the financial backing of big donors.

"They are effectively broke and I don't see the clouds parting and the sun coming out on their fundraising abilities," he said.

'DETRIMENTAL TO CAMPAIGNS'

The review of the two Republican state parties' filings shows that a near shut-off of the donor spigot is contributing to their financial woes.

The Michigan party's federal account took in $51,000 in the fist three months of this year, putting it on pace to raise less than a quarter of its haul in the first half of 2019, the same period in the last presidential election cycle.

In March, Karamo told a gathering of local officials that the party had $460,000 in liabilities after the 2022 midterm elections. While not unusually large, the debt would normally be covered by fresh fundraising.

The Arizona party, meanwhile, raised roughly $139,000 in the first three months of this year, according to state and federal filings. In the comparable period in 2019, in the months after the 2018 midterm elections, it raised more than $330,000.

New Arizona chair DeWit, who was NASA's chief financial officer in the Trump administration, is working to make the party attractive to donors again by focusing on winning elections, spokesperson Zlaticanin said.

Some donors in Michigan said they had started talking with each other about how best to bypass the state party and support individual Republican candidates. But the state party's organizational heft will be hard to replicate, said Jeff Timmer, a former executive director of the Michigan Republican Party.

"You have to have boots on the ground and you can't build that kind of infrastructure quickly enough to win the 2024 election," Timmer said.

Jonathan Lines, who preceded Ward as Arizona's party chairman up to 2019, said he expected new donor money to mostly go to political action committees, and other groups who fund campaigns, rather than the state party.

"But not having the state party well funded is detrimental to many Republican campaigns next year," he added.
